questions.question_text:
MANAGING A STAGE BOUNDARY -
The cost tolerance for stage 3 is forecast to be exceeded. The project manager has therefore decided to remove the ‘updated corporate quality procedures’ from the scope of the project. This would allow the stage to be delivered within time and cost. The project manager has produced an exception plan to present this recommendation to the project board.
Is this appropriate, and why?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
the project manager shoud raise an exception REPORT to the board. One of Board's possible responses would be to request an exception report.. It is not certain. Another option could be chosen as "amend tolerances".

choices.C: No, because exception plans are requested by the project board in response to an exception report.
choices.D: No, because the current stage is forecast to exceed approved limits.
choices.B: Yes, because scope tolerance can be used to protect time and cost tolerances.
choices.A: Yes, because an exception plan is required when a stage is forecast to exceed the tolerances set.

questions.question_text:
PRINCIPLES -
An external consultancy is developing the ‘e-learning course’. The Business Development Director has been appointed as senior supplier to ensure that the right technology is used for the ‘e-learning course’.
How well does the appointment apply the ‘defined roles and responsibilities’ principle?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I think its B - The statement "It applies it poorly, because the senior supplier should ensure that the project outputs meet the business needs" is incorrect; the senior supplier's primary focus is on the technical integrity and quality of the project outputs, not the overall business needs. The senior user and executive are responsible for ensuring that the project outputs meet the business needs and that the project delivers the stated benefits

choices.D: It applies it poorly, because members of Learn-it’s corporate board should be project board members.
choices.B: It applies it well, because key decisions about the ‘e-learning course’ should be made before the work starts.
choices.C: It applies it poorly, because the senior supplier should ensure that the project outputs meet the business needs.
choices.A: It applies it well, because projects should engage those who provide expertise to the project.

choices.C: No, because the project manager should check the operations and maintenance interfaces in the work package first.
choices.A: Yes, because an exception report should be used to request guidance on how this situation should be handled.
choices.D: No, because the team plan should be discussed with the supplier to check whether work will be completed on time.
choices.B: Yes, because there is zero time tolerance for this stage the checkpoint report must be delivered on time.

questions.question_text:
The project is in stage 3. Zero time tolerance has been given for this stage. When checking progress, the project manager noticed that the checkpoint report from the external supplier of the 'e-learning course' is late. As work package progress information is missing, the project manager has decided to raise an exception report.
Is this an appropriate action, and why?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
It states that the checkpoint report is late, not that the product delivery. The project manager just did not receive information. This is not a situation to raise an exception report. I think D is the correct answer. Also, the same question is in Edition 6 and the answer there is D.

Selected Answer: C
C is the answer

Selected Answer: C
The project manager has to do the below when planning initiation stage during starting up a project. Identifying stages is not included. It will be done during initiation stage when creating the project plan. My opinion :)
--> decide suitable management controls for the initiation stage activities, based on the project approach.

●  identify any constraints on time and costs for the initiation stage and produce the stage plan for this stage according to the principles and techniques in Chapter 7.

●  review any risks in the project log and assess their impact on the stage plan for the initiation stage. If any new risks are identified (or existing ones have changed), update the project log.

choices.A: Yes, because the work of the initiation stage needs to be planned and approved, in the same way as other project work.
choices.D: No, because the senior supplier is responsible for assessing the viability of the project approach.
choices.B: Yes, because the management controls for the initiation stage need to be defined and approved by the project board.
choices.C: No, because subsequent stages are planned in the initiation stage as part of creating the project plan.

questions.question_text:
During the 'starting up a project process', the project manager discusses the standard model for course development with the executive. The project manager then assesses how the Health and Safety Training Project will be delivered, including what products should be delivered in each stage.
Is this an appropriate way to carry out the 'plan the initiation stage' activity, and why?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Quality responsibilities are typically detailed in the Quality Management Strategy or Quality Plan, but they are not a part of the composition of a Plan itself. The composition of a Plan generally includes pre-requisites, assumptions, and product descriptions.

Selected Answer: C
Quality responsibilities is not in the Plan (see A.16.2), but in the Product Description (A.17.2).
